_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Process vessel (A1-123C ) external inspection in #1 Ammonia Plant
_prev_prog_3.Description: The Verdigris Nitrogen Facility has a comprehensive Prevention/Process Safety Management (PSM) Program and is subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's standard for process safety management of highly hazardous chemicals found at 29 CFR Part 1910.119.  Key elements of the PSM program include: 1) stringent design standards of equipment which incorporate substantial safety factors and include state of the art monitoring and control instrumentation; 2) extensive process safety information that is accurate and up to date; 3) well trained operating, maintenance and contract personnel; 4) written safety, operating, and maintenance procedures; 5) mechanical integrity procedures for process equipment inspections and quality control; 6) management of change and pre-startup review procedures; 7) periodic, detailed evaluation of each process area by a team utilizing HAZOP methodology; 8) regular PSM program audits; and 9) employee participation in every element of the PSM program.  The Verdigris Nitrogen Facility process is nitrogen fertilizer manufacturing which consists of nine interconnected and co-located production/storage units.  These units have similar prevention program elements and are listed together in Section 7.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
I. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Operating in a safe and responsible manner is a core value and an integral part of CF Industries. Our safety strategy revolves around our "Do It Right" value and permeates our business in three key ways:

? Robust systems that provide a clear, repeatable direction toward excellence.

? Superior performance that aligns effective and efficient EHS activities with operations.

? Engaged culture that empowers consistent behaviors that drive toward excellence.

CF Industries works closely with emergency responders and other local officials to develop detailed emergency response plans that extend beyond our physical operating locations.



VERDIGRIS NITROGEN FACILITY AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Verdigris Nitrogen Facility manufactures anhydrous ammonia, urea ammonium nitrate (UAN) solution, and other nitrogen products.  Intermediates in the manufacture of these products include nitric acid, urea solution, and ammonium nitrate solution.  An ancillary substance that is present at the facility is chlorine. The regulated substances, as defined by 40 CFR Part 68, which are present at the facility in more than a threshold quantity are ammonia, chlorine, and flammable mixture. 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Verdigris Nitrogen Facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with all of the accidental release and chemical-specific prevention requirements as set forth in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 40 CFR Part 68. This facility is also subject to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard 29 CFR 1910.119. The following summarizes the elements of the release and chemical-specific prevention that are in place at our facility:  

? Process safety information that is accurate and up to date;

? Well-trained operating, maintenance, and contract personnel;

? Written operating procedures;

? Me

e ERP is designed as a guide to help in determining the magnitude of an incident, the steps needed to bring the incident under control and the requirements to ensure that all federal, state, and local laws are complied with. The ERP is a definitive plan that assigns responsibilities, defines several different methods of communication, designates evacuation procedures, and coordinates with outside assistance. The plan also designates the type and frequency of training that employees are required to have depending on their responsibilities. Furthermore, the plan commits the company's management team to devote the necessary resources to prepare, implement and audit the ERP.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Rigorous training, drills, audits, cooperation with emergency responders and local officials, recognition programs and participation in industry safety initiatives help keep our focus on what it takes to "Do It Right." Through our ongoing commitment to make our facility as safe as possible for employees, contractors, the community, and the environment, we are always continuously improving our systems and practices.
